My last tweet on this subject: post-GFC economy has been constrained by factors beyond scope of monetary policy and Fed’s policies may have caused financial distortions & unintended (or unkown) consequences (echoing Peter Fisher’s thinking)

Perhaps, but every side being debated is a counter-factual ... we will never know whether the economy would be better or worse if the Fed (or politicians, or business leaders) had done something different ... I like to think in shades of gray, not black-and-white

I think it was perhaps a psychological negative and there were diminishing returns to consider as well as unintended consequences- like forcing investors out the risk spectrum and asset inflation (all of which the Fed has conceded many times) ... that’s all I’ve been positing
Low rates didn’t make recovery weak; but low rates didn’t provide the boost to growth or inflation that the Fed was anticipating (it did boost asset prices; just not real economy prices)
I never read it

Not making a cause-and-effect argument ... just don’t think the Fed keeping rates at 0 was the primary driver of why wage growth picked up ... other forces at play (including strong corporate earnings)

No, it wouldn’t have “fixed” that problem ... just think there’s a case to be made that the Fed maintaining unprecedented easy policy for so long didn’t produce the economic boost they were hoping for (which they admit)
Debt, delveraging and deflationary mindset kept people from borrowing
ZIRP did nothing to raise AHE ... wages have been rising as the Fed’s been raisingpic.twitter.com/dWfHfr1IAJ
How did ZIRP and a $4.5t balance sheet do in terms of boosting growth? All that said, speculating on what would’ve been is simply counter factual analysis.

I guess I would just posit that the Fed keeping rates so low for so long (treating the economic patient like it was perpetually in the ER) actually contributed to what has been the weakest recovery/expansion (including wages) in history
